sections.title: The FINITE STRING Newsletter Announcements Announcements Second Office Automation Conference
paragraphs: The Albert Thomas Convention Center in Houston, Texas will be the site of the second annual AFIPS Office Automation Conference (OAC) March 23-25, 1981. "Investing in Productivity" is this year's conference theme, and over 200 speakers have been scheduled in more than 60 learning sessions. The focus of these sessions will be directed at the way in which automation technologies can be harnessed and integrated to increase productivity and effectiveness of office workers. Sessions will include such topics as Feasibility Studies, Organizational Impact, Systems Architecture, Electronic Mail, Teleconferencing, and State-of-the-Art in Word Processing.

For information and registration forms contact: Ms. Carol Sturgeon AFIPS - OAC - P.O. Box 9658 1815 North Lynn Street - Suite 800 Arlington, Virginia 22209 (703) 558-3613 ACL to sponsor two sessions at NCC '81

The 1981 National Computer Conference, sponsored by AFIPS, will be held at McCormick Place in Chicago, May 4-7, 1981. In addition to the technical program consisting of papers, panels, surveys and tutorials, there will be a series of one-day professional development seminars and the largest exhibit of computer products and services in the world.

The use of robots and artificial intelligence will be among the program sessions at the Personal Computing Festival which will be held during the Conference, and personal computing exhibits will appear in the main exhibit area for the first time.

ACL will sponsor two sessions at the NCC, organized by a committee consisting of Martha Evens, Jane Robinson, Norm Sondheimer and Don Walker. One is a paper session, chaired by Martha Evens, on the topic, "Communicating with Computers in Natural Language - Current Capabilities," which will have the following three talks:
Issues in the Development of Natural Language

Front- Ends James Hendler, Thomas Kehler, Paul Michaelis, Brian Phillips, Kenneth Ross and Harry Tennant, Texas Instruments Text-Critiquing with the EPISTLE System: An Author's Aid to Better Syntax Lance Miller, George Heidorn and Karen Jensen, IBM T.J. Watson Research Center Shifting to a Higher Gear in a Natural Language System Bozena Thompson and Frederick Thompson, California Institute of Technology

The other ACL session is a panel session, chaired by Norm Sondheimer, on the topic, "Communicating with Computers in Natural Language - Future Promises," with the following four participants: Applications for the Handicapped Madeleine Bates, Bolt Beranek and Newman Business Applications Larry Harris, Artificial Intelligence Corp. Military Applications Christine Montgomery, Operating Systems, Inc. Medical Applications Donald Walker, SRI International
The ACL will also hold a special one-day meeting
in conjunction with the 1981 LSA Winter Meeting in
New York City in December. More information about
this will appear in later issues of the AJCL.

The Fifth International Conference on Computers in the Humanities is scheduled for May 17-20, 1981, in Ann Arbor, Michigan, sponsored by the University of Michigan, Association for Computers in the Humanities, and Association for Literary and Linguistic Computing in cooperation with ACM SIGLASH (Language Analysis and Studies in the Humanities). Contributions are invited that present the results of computer-assisted research and creation in the arts. Send inquiries and one-page abstracts before February 15, 1981, to:
Richard W. Bailey
Department of English
The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor, Michigan 48109

This will be followed immediately by the Third Conference on Data Bases in the Humanities and Social Sciences (Joint Conference on Easier and More Productive Use of Computing Systems), May 20-22, also in Ann Arbor, sponsored by the Association for Computers in the Humanities and the University of Michigan. This conference has two facets: the quality of the human interface and the characteristics of data American Journal of Computational Linguistics, Volume 6, Number 3-4, July-December 1980 193 The FINITE STRING Newsletter Announcements
base applications. The conference is intended as inte-
grating the insights of the social sciences, humanities,
computer science, and human factors engineering.

(313) 763-3482 Symposium on Text Manipulation

The ACM Special Interest Groups on Programming Languages and Office Automation will jointly sponsor a Symposium on Text Manipulation, June 8-10, 1981, in Portland, Oregon. This symposium will deal with the variety of tools, techniques and programs that have been developed for creating and manipulating text, whether natural language text or programming language text. The emphasis is to be on ideas that can be generalized beyond the context in which they were originally developed. The conference chairman is:
Paul Abrahams

The Seventh International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence will be held in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, August 24-28, 1981. Topics of interest include natural language processing, knowledge representation, expert systems and cognitive science. Papers must be submitted to the program committee by March 1, 1981, in one of the following categories: papers (6,000 words max.), communications (1,200 words max.), and programs (500 words max.).

The 1981 ACM Annual Conference will be held at the Bonaventure Hotel in Los Angeles, California, November 9-11, 1981, and will feature presentations on a wide variety of topics that are of interest to today's computer professional. The program committee is soliciting contributions in the form of tutorials, proposals for panel discussions, and short technical papers or surveys. Work that addresses areas of practical importance is especially welcome. Technical papers should focus on innovations or recent advances, and should stress the connection between theory and application. Suggested topics include artificial intelligence, office automation, data base systems, and personal computing.
Four copies of papers (maximum 12 double-spaced
pages in length) should be submitted by March 7,
1981, to: ACM '81 - Call for Papers Village Station P.O. Box 24059 Los Angeles, California 90024 Workshops on Semantics and Representation of Knowledge being held in New York

In February 1980, a series of monthly workshops on the semantics of natural language and issues of representing knowledge was started at the IBM Systems Research Institute in New York City. The workshops are open to research workers and graduate students in the fields of artificial intelligence, cognitive psychology, computational linguistics, data base semantics, linguistics, philosophy, psycholinguistics, and symbolic logic. Nine meetings were held in 1980 with 17 speakers and about 100 attendees, many of whom came to nearly every session. 194 American Journal of Computational Linguistics, Volume 6, Number 3-4, July-December 1980 The FINITE STRING Newsletter Announcements
